cards.back: VCC = ICQ(R4 + R5) + VCEQ. Used to find R4 once R5, VCEQ, and ICQ are known.

cards.front: What is R5 in this design and why 220Ω?
cards.back: R5 is PNP emitter resistor. 220Ω chosen so ICQ (25mA) >> IL_peak (3.5mA), giving stiff output that doesn't shift when load is connected.
150Ω (closest E12). This makes ICQ = (15-6)/370 = 24.3mA instead of 25mA — acceptable.

cards.front: Power dissipation formula and Q2 result?
cards.back: P = VCEQ × ICQ = 6V × 24.3mA = 146mW. Maximum is 500mW — safe.

cards.front: What is VB2 and why does it matter?
cards.back: VB2 ≈ 10.7V = VC1. It is the voltage that Stage 1's collector must provide to bias Q2 correctly through direct coupling.
R_AC = R5∥RL = 220×1000/(220+1000) = 180.3Ω. Co shorts at AC frequency, putting R5 in parallel with RL.

cards.front: Available AC voltage swing from Q-point?

cards.back: IBQ2 = ICQ/hFE = 24.3/120 = 0.2mA = 200μA. This must be supplied by Stage 1.
The DC operating conditions barely change when the load is connected. Achieved when R5 << RL (or ICQ >> IL_peak).

cards.front: What are the final Stage 2 resistor values?
cards.back: R4 = 150Ω, R5 = 220Ω (both E12). Total: R4+R5 = 370Ω. DC load line slope = -1/370.
